Field.Label:
To START, here the basic steps: 1. in CONFIG setup at minimum userID,PassWD, ipNumber of indigo server 2. Setup of physical rPi servers: ssh pi@ipnumber password default = pibeacon passwd to change default pasword sudo raspi-config to set time zone, expand SD .., get ip number of RPI w ifconfig 3. in menu Initial BASIC setup of rPi servers set ipNumber, userID, password of RPI# x (0-19)
4. Now wait until the first ibeacon and RPI devices show up in indigo If nothing happens, do a Send Config/Restart/PGM/Sound/... to send all files to RPI, then ssh to RPI and check programs that are running: ps -ef | grep .py At minimum master.py, beaconloop.py, receiveGPIOcommands.py should be running if installLibs.py is running, it is updating op-sys files. That might take several hours 5. You then want to disable accept new beacons in config any car driving by likely has some beacons sending messages. To add new beacons set accept new beacons to eg -60 dBm Put your new beacon onto the rpi, wait a minute and check the new beacon(s) created Set accept new beacons to off in config Then move the beacon far away and check again, find the beacon that has the signal reduced Then move it back to the RPI and check if signal is high again. Then set the beacon at 1m distance and note the signal strength. Edit the beacon and set TX power to that value(it is likely ~ -60). That will make the distance calulation more accurate
Other remarks... 1. Some beacon types are automatically recognized by the plugin: xy (V1-3), Nonda iHere and Aiko, spotypal, ruuvitag, ... checkout the file "knownBeaconTags.full_copy_to_use_as_example" in the plugin prefrence directory for a full list Using these types makes your live much easier 2. It is advisable to have at least 2 RPI that "see" each other (in bluetooth range) that makes the overall system more stable and enables location mapping in x,y,z coordinates The location mapping gets much better if you have an RPI in each room
